Authors:
Yunheng Ji, Jin Yang, Jacob B. Landis, Shuying Wang, Lei
Jin, Pingxuan Xie, Jun-Bo Yang, Tingshuang Yi
Title:
Genome skimming contributes to clarifying taxonomic confusion
in plant species delimitation: A case study of Paris section Axiparis
(Melanthiaceae)
Journal:
Frontiers in Plant Science, section Plant Systematics and
Evolution
Keywords: Plastome, ribosomal DNA, species boundary, taxonomy
Abstract:
lant species delimitation is a difficult task in
traditional morphology-based taxonomy. The genome skimming approach has
been increasingly used for phylogenetic analysis and species
identification in recent years. Yet, the efficacy of this approach in
plant species delimitation remains poorly understood. Here, we carried
out a case study in the taxonomically perplexing taxa, Paris L. section
Axiparis H. Li (Melanthiaceae), to investigate the performance of the
genome skimming approach in delineating species boundaries. We employed
a genome skimming method to recover the plastid genomes (plastomes) and
nuclear ribosomal DNA (nrDNA) regions of 51 individual plants from all
the nine described species of P. sect. Axiparis by sampling multiple
accessions per species. The species boundaries within the taxonomically
perplexing plant lineage were critically explored using phylogenetic
inference and multiple sequence-based species delimitation methods. Our
data indicate that only two species-level taxonomic units that possess
not only morphological uniqueness but also genetic distinctiveness and
evolutionary independence can be recognized in P. sect. Axiparis. This
study deciphers species delimitation in P. sect. Axiparis, and suggests
that the genome skimming approach has great promise for developing a
rigorous species delimitation framework in taxonomically perplexing
plant taxa.
